document.ModsDocTitle: Systematics of Neotropical microteiid lizards (Gymnophthalmidae, Cercosaurinae), with the description of a new genus and species from the Andean montane forests
document.docAuthor: Moravec, Jiri, Smid, Jiri, Stundl, Jan & Lehr, Edgar
document.docTitle: Selvasaura Moravec, Smid, Stundl & Lehr, 2018, gen. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Systematics of Neotropical microteiid lizards (Gymnophthalmidae, Cercosaurinae), with the description of a new genus and species from the Andean montane forests

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Systematics of Neotropical microteiid lizards (Gymnophthalmidae, Cercosaurinae), with the description of a new genus and species from the Andean montane forests

caption.paragraph: Table 3. Mean uncorrected genetic distances (p-distances, in %) between cercosaurine genera or their monophyletic clades if the genus' monophyly was not supported. Below diagonal are values based on the 12S alignment, above on the 16S. Values for Selvasaura gen. n. are in bold.

Table 4. Mean uncorrected genetic distances (p-distances, in %) between cercosaurine genera or their monophyletic clades if the genus' monophyly was not supported. Below diagonal are values based on the ND4 alignment, above on the cmos. Values for Selvasaura gen. n. are in bold. Note that compared to Table 3 some clades are missing here because they did not have the ND4 and cmos sequences available (" Echinosaura " sulcarostrum , Unnamed clade 4).

subSubSection.paragraph: (1) head shields smooth; (2) frontoparietal and parietal shields paired; (3) frontonasal, frontal and interparietal shields single; (4) prefrontal shields present; (5) lower palpebral disc transparent, not divided; (6) loreal shield present; (7) scale organs on labials present; (8) anteriormost supraocular and anteriormost superciliary shields fused; (9) dorsal surface of the tongue covered by scale-like papillae; (10) nuchal scales smooth; (11) dorsal scales rectangular, slightly rugose; (12) ventral scales squared to rectangular, smooth; (13) limbs pentadactyl, digits clawed; (14) femoral pores present in males, absent in females; (15) hemipenial lobes large, distinct from the hemipenial body.

The generic name Selvasaura is derived from the Spanish noun 'selva' (forest) and the Greek noun σαύρα (lizard; saura is the feminine form) and refers to the habitat (montane rainforest) of the type species.
